title-group.article-title: Patient decision aids – a tool for shared decision-making

abstract.p: The 2010 NHS White Paper Equity and Excellence: Liberating the NHS proposed that the principle of ‘shared decision-making’ would become the norm so that patients could routinely participate in choices over their healthcare. In order to make decisions, both doctors and patients need information. Clinicians can draw on evidence-based guidelines, trials, books and personal experience, but not all these resources are suitable for the public and the constraints of a standard consultation can make explanations challenging. Traditionally, patient education materials have been used to describe diagnoses and treatments. However, some situations require patients to deliberate carefully on a range of different therapies, all of which carry risks and benefits. For these cases there are now specially designed ‘decision aids’ that assist patients to consider the options and come to an agreed plan with their doctor. Although widely available, these tools are not routinely used in clinical practice. The aims of this paper are to explain the ideas behind decision aids, how they may be used and where to access them. We will also review the evidence for their effectiveness and discuss challenges to incorporating them in consultations.

sec.title: The GP curriculum and patient decision aids
sec.p:
Contextual statement 2.04: Enhancing professional knowledge states that general practitioners should:
Be able to apply evidence in the context of the patient, the community and the healthcare setting
Base decision-making on good evidence-based practice, taking into account patient values in order to provide the most appropriate care for the patient
Be aware of how you impart information about evidence so that patients can best understand relevant evidence and be helped in making a decision
Understand that patients may wish to self-manage, independent of or according to their own interpretation of scientific knowledge, making their own choices based on their own understanding and values

sec.title: What is a patient decision aid?
sec.p: A patient decision aid (also called simply a ‘decision aid’, ‘informed decision aid’ or ‘brief decision aid’) is a tool to help physicians and patients consider different medical options related to a specific medical scenario. They provide accessible, evidence-based information on what choices are available together with their respective risks and benefits. The choices are presented in the form of lists or sections of a website, together with a detailed explanation. Likely outcomes are described and presented numerically or pictorially to demonstrate the relative probabilities. The more complex decision aids go beyond decision support through describing risks and benefits. Some offer guidance on weighing risks and benefits according to personal priorities. The ‘values clarification exercise’ is one example of such guidance. No patient decision aid, however, is designed to be used in isolation from medical input. Before embarking on a decision aid the doctor must ensure that the tool fits the diagnosis as well as highlighting any possible differentials. Clinicians are also key to checking patients’ understanding, discussing remaining concerns and ensuring the preferred decision is appropriate in the medical context.

The number of decision aids has been steadily growing in the last two decades. These have been produced by a range of different organisations, and have been aimed at various medical decisions from screening to major surgery. The expansion and diversity of decision aids has led to a formalisation of their definition. The International Patient Decision Aids Standards Collaboration describes them as ‘tools designed to prepare clients to participate in making speciﬁc and deliberated choices among healthcare options’ (IPDAS, 2005). The broad aims of decision aids have also been summarised in the Cochrane review of their effectiveness (see Box 1) (Stacey et al., 2011). Box 1.
Aims of patient decision aids.
• Provide evidence-based information about a health condition, the options, associated benefits, harms, probabilities and scientific uncertainties • Help patients clarify the values they place on the benefits, harms and scientific uncertainties • Provide structured guidance in the steps of decision-making and communication of their informed values to others involved in the decision (e.g. family, clinician)

sec.title: Conceptual background
sec.p:
The development of patient decision aids draws heavily on the shared model of medical decision making (Charles et al., 1999). This style of consultation can be seen as an enhanced form of informed choice where information flows between doctor and patient in both directions so that the discussion and ultimate decision is a collaborative one. A definition of shared decision-making is given in Box 2. Greater involvement of patients in decisions over their care has been a gradual trend over recent decades and reflects changes in attitudes to personal autonomy and medical authority. Whilst respect for personal autonomy provides a strong ethical argument for shared decision-making, proponents of the process cite clinical benefits as a further incentive. One such proponent, the Kings Fund, argues that shared decision-making results in improved patient outcomes and reduces unwarranted variation in clinical practice (Coulter and Collins, 2011). Box 2.
Kings Fund definition of ‘shared decision-making’.
‘… a process in which clinicians and patients work together to select tests, treatments, management or support packages, based on clinical evidence and the patient’s informed preferences. It involves the provision of evidence-based information about options, outcomes and uncertainties, together with decision support counselling and a system for recording and implementing patients’ informed preferences.' (Coulter and Collins, 2011)

sec.title: What is available
sec.p:
At present the major UK organisations producing decision aids are NHS Direct, Patient.co.uk, the National Prescribing Centre and the Cardiff University Decision Laboratory (www.optiongrid.co.uk). Under development are also 36 new tools from an organisation called Totally Health, commissioned by the Department of Health as part of its QIPP ‘Right Care’ programme. The earliest decision aids came in a range of formats, such as leaflets, audio cassette and video, but the vast majority are now internet-based. Some (such as on Patient.co.uk and the National Prescribing Centre) are still intended to be printed but others (such as NHS Direct) are fully interactive, incorporating patient stories and tools to guide choices. A selection of publically available patient decision aids relevant to UK primary care is given in Table 1. Table 1.

The most complete repository of publically available decision aids is held by the Ottawa Hospital Research Institute at decisionaid.ohri.ca. Although tools are now available internationally in various languages (see www.thedecisionaidcollection.nl) their use is most established in the USA. A major producer has been the Informed Medical Decisions Foundation, a non-profit organisation that promotes shared decisions in healthcare. Commercial organisations also now exist that produce proprietary decision aids as well as a range of educational materials (for instance Health Dialog www.healthdialog.com and Health Wise www.healthwise.org). A selection of the commercial tools can be accessed via the Ottawa repository, but are likely to be aimed at an American audience.

sec.title: When is a decision aid appropriate?
sec.p: Use of a decision aid is most appropriate when choice is likely to be strongly influenced by a patient’s attitude to different benefits and harms. This particularly applies when no single option has clear superiority, or all carry risks, and a trade-off needs to be made between them. Real world examples would include hormone replacement therapy, the management of knee osteoarthritis and screening tests for prostate cancer. O’Connor and Stacey (2005) have described these treatments as ‘grey zone’, contrasting with ‘white zone’ (clear benefit over harm) and ‘black zone’ (clear harm over benefit). In ‘grey zone’ treatments, achieving a clear understanding of the individual’s priorities can be crucial to guiding therapy, since patients evaluate potential outcomes differently.

sec.title: How to use a patient decision aid
sec.p:
Different types of decision aid need to be used differently. Interactive, web-based decision aids are likely to be too time-consuming for use during a consultation, but may be ideal for patients to use either before or following discussion with a doctor. Other decision aids are briefer and are a useful adjunct to a consultation when printed off and used face to face. Ultimately the approach will vary depending on the patient and the decision involved. For choices around medication, the National Prescribing Centre suggests using a five-step method (see Box 3). Box 3.
How to use a patient decision aid.
1. Describe the clinical decision (e.g. anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation) 2. Describe the treatment options (e.g. no treatment, aspirin, warfarin) and outline the dilemma (all treatments have risks and benefits) 3. Offer a further, more detailed discussion (some patients may opt to defer the decision to the health professional at this point) 4. Work through the patient decision aid if appropriate 5. Allow the patient time to consider their choice. They may wish to take away a copy of the decision aid to discuss it with others *Adapted from 'How to use patient decision aids' from www.npc.nhs.uk/patient_decision_aids/pda.php

The use of decision aids as an adjunct to promote shared decision-making is also described in a paper by Elwyn et al. (2012). It divides the process into three stages and proposes use of decision aids in the second part—'option talk'—to support the transition from initial preferences to informed preferences (see Fig. 1). Some examples of clinical scenarios that make use of decision aids are given in Table 2. Figure 1.
A shared decision-making model.

Table 2.
Case scenarios involving patient decision aids
Knee OA – surgery or conservative? • 65-year-old woman who has tried painkillers and physiotherapy but frustrated at lack of lasting benefit • Asks GP for referral as feels operation is only option • Recommended to go through decision aid on www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk • Once understands lengthy recovery and problems with kneeling following surgery decides to postpone as wants to take full part in caring for grandchildren • Gains further ideas on self-management • Starts taking glucosamine and asks GP to refer her for knee injection prior to next family visit
Atrial fibrillation – aspirin or warfarin? • 68-year-old hypertensive man, who is a keen cyclist, found to have atrial fibrillation • Concerned about risk of bleeding and need for monitoring with warfarin as still very active • Goes through decision aid featuring Cates Plots* at www.npc.co.uk • Appreciates substantially greater stroke protection afforded by warfarin • Accepts higher risk of bleeding compared to aspirin as difference is relatively small
PSA – to test or not to test? • 70-year-old man having some urinary flow problems and concerned about prostate cancer • Goes to GP and asks about PSA test • Recommended to go through decision aid at www.prosdex.com using decision scale • Decides to go ahead and result comes back slightly raised • Is prepared for biopsies, accepts not foolproof but would prefer increased reassurance • Feels sufficiently informed to decline second round of biopsies when one of eight samples comes back as abnormal
*
Cates Plots are pictorial representations of likely benefits and harms from a treatment. See www.nntonline.net.

sec.title: Evidence for effect of decision aids
sec.p: Although decision aids have only relatively recently become accessible to clinicians, their effectiveness has been under evaluation since the late 1990s. Early studies which looked at patient acceptability showed mostly positive results, with later trials testing the impact on patient understanding of risk. Two early reviews, which summarised key studies (O’Connor et al., 1999a, 1999b) found that decision aids performed well, compared to usual care, in terms of educating patients on therapeutic choices and their respective risks/benefits. Some of the included trials also assessed how prepared patients felt to make a decision by producing a ‘decisional conflict’ score; results also showed a slight superiority of decision aids over usual care.

Later Cochrane reviews have confirmed that decision aids improve patient knowledge scores and better prepare patients to make an informed choice. They have also synthesized the evidence base as to which aspects of decision aids are particularly beneficial. For example, a review by Stacey et al. (2011) showed that more detailed decision aids were superior at raising patient knowledge than simpler ones. In addition, risk perceptions were more accurate when decision aids included expressed probabilities; this effect was strongest using numbers rather than words. Other aims of decision aids are to help patients communicate their preferences and participate more in medical decision-making and evidence shows that consultations involving decision aids are more patient-led. O’Connor et al. (1999a, 1999b) found that, compared to usual care, they significantly increased levels of patient participation. Similarly, Stacey et al. (2011) found that they increased the likelihood of shared decision-making and reduced levels of passive decision-making.

Whilst the impact of decision aids on patient education and participation appears to be broadly positive (see Box 4), the evidence for the effect on patient actions is more mixed. In the 2011 Cochrane review, lower rates of elective surgery (coronary revascularisation for ischaemic heart disease, orchiectomy for prostate cancer and mastectomy for early-stage breast cancer) were found amongst patients exposed to decision aids. In contrast, rates of other operations, such as child circumcision, have not shown an effect. Similarly, the review identified evidence for reduced uptake of PSA screening, but trials relating to prenatal and breast cancer genetic testing showed no difference. Regarding medication use, the picture is similarly unclear. One trial by Thomson et al. (2007) for decisions around anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation found significantly fewer patients opting for warfarin after using a decision aid (4 of 16 intervention patients compared to 15 of 16 controls). However, this result has not been replicated, and the majority of trials relating to medication show no difference in uptake. Neither do decision aids appear to significantly alter general or condition-specific health outcomes. Box 4.
Positive effects of using a patient decision aid.
• Improved knowledge of options • More realistic expectations • More certain and supported in decision • More active in decision-making • Fewer remaining undecided • Greater agreement between choice and values
Source: Stacey et al. (2011).

sec.title: Challenges to implementation
sec.p: Despite emerging evidence of benefit, ethical motivation and political support, use of decision aids (and shared decision-making more generally) is not routine practice. A review of physician attitudes towards the two concepts highlighted some possible barriers to implementation. Physicians were concerned that decision aids took too much time, were not applicable to their patient groups and did not accurately reflect their patients’ clinical conditions (Gravel et al., 2006). Interestingly the latest Cochrane review did not find evidence for an increase in consultation length when a decision aid was used. Also, with over 500 decision aids currently available, it seems likely that many clinical scenarios would be applicable. However, patient characteristics may well inhibit their use. Most are English language only and all require reading ability. Similarly, the growing number of internet-based decision aids will only be suitable if both doctors and patients have technological ability and access to the required IT resources.

Perhaps the greatest challenge for practitioners is knowing what is available and where to find it. Decision aids are produced by different organisations and distributed via different websites. Each producer has addressed different medical scenarios and the tools themselves vary considerably in level of detail, length and style. Consequently, routine use of decision aids by practitioners will require a reasonable level of prior familiarity in order to select one that fits both the medical context and the patient’s abilities.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Decision aids can enhance a patient’s knowledge of their options, reduce their level of uncertainty and ensure that their values are incorporated into decision-making. They promote patient participation in consultations and increase the likelihood of shared decision-making. Some trials have shown they affect patient choices—for example reduced uptake of major surgery—though their effect in other areas such as genetic testing and medication is less clear.

Increased patient participation in medical decisions has a strong ethical basis on grounds of autonomy and is supported by recent social trends and government legislation. Greater use of decision aids is one way doctors can facilitate a shared style of medical management and ensure that treatment options reflect patients’ priorities. They are designed for use within the context of a shared medical model and support, but do not replace a physician’s general consultation skills. Prior familiarity with the range of tools available can help match the style, length and format to the patient’s characteristics and clinical situation.

list-item.p: There is now a large number of publically available patient decision aids
They are aimed at decisions where there is no single best answer or a balance of costs and benefits have to be weighed up
Decision aids are designed to provide evidence-based information on medical options and help patients clarify their preferences
Compared to usual care, they improve patient knowledge and result in more accurate risk perceptions
Decision aids lead to more patient-led consultations and greater shared decision-making
There is some evidence that decision aids reduce the uptake of major elective surgery
